newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot propane takes a beating from NYMEX.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot propane takes a beating from NYMEX.

text.p: U.S. spot propane prices took a beating in quiet late trade on Thursday as NYMEX futures plunged on Iraqi news, players said.

NYMEX December crude oil futures ended down 93 cents at $23.35 a barrel following news rival Kurdish factions have agreed to extend a U.S. brokered cease-fire that ended two months of clashes in northern Iraq.
The extension renewed hopes that a long awaited Iraqi oil-for-food deal will finally be implemented.
Crude oil pulled the rest of the energy complex down.

In the U.S. Gulf Coast, Mont Belvieu, Texas, spot propane fell about one cent in thin talk to between 52.25 cents and 53.00 cents a gallon. The market was difficult to gauge because there were few buyers, players said.
In the Midwest, Conway, Kansas, hub material shed one cent to 54.50/55.00 cents. Traders said there were few sellers in that hub.
"A lot of sellers think the market is going to pop back up," said one Conway trader.
Belvieu normal butane was also assessed lower, down 1.75 cents to 54.00/54.50 cents. Conway material was a quarter cent higher.
-- Laney Salisbury, New York Energy Desk +1 212 859 1631
